comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per the digitised newspapers, Thomas Woodliffe, 65, painter, residing at 344 Glenmore Rd, Paddington, died following a fall at the Bayswater Hotel in June 1897 (lower lh column) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page1361291 ; so there's a good chance that the sign shown here is at his house at 344 Glenmore Rd ; this advert for two painters (in column 2) suggests that Woodliffe might have been living at Rushcutters Bay in November 1880 (though maybe this northern end of Paddington was then known as Rushcutters Bay...I think that's still the case...) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13476032 ; As far as I'm aware, the first incarnation of the Sydney 'Daily Telegraph' began in 1883...So going on these scraps, you'd think that the pic was taken between ca. 1883 and maybe some time after Woodliffe's death (here keeping in mind that signs have a habit of remaining up indefinitely)...which is not exactly a revelation. Maybe a traffic historian might be able to tell us when angle parking (or perpendicular parking) for horses was introduced. The telegraph poles appear to be the older no cross-arm type - www.sydneyarchitecture.com/cbd/cbd3-003.htm Are the horse and cart parked in ? Alma Street or is this a lane?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I don't think that is Glenmore Road

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Yes, I'd say that Glenmore Rd is obscured here. I gather that Glenmore Rd would be the street sporting the line of telegraph poles.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I think the horse and cart may be in the right-angled James Lane, looking north.
